questions.text: Identify the structure shown in NCCT of Nose and Paranasal Sinuses ( marked with arrow)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Concha Bullosa

Ref: Read the text below

Sol: 

• Agger nasi is the anterior most anterior ethmoidal air cell. 

• Supreme turbinate is a variation. It is another small turbinate sometimes present above superior turbinate.

• Concha bullosa means pneumatized middle turbinate. 

• Anterior ethmoid air cells are from 2-8.Posterior ethmoid air cells are 1-8

• Haller cell are anterior ethmoid air cells lying in floor of orbit

• Anterior and posterior ethmoid air cells are separated by basal lamella

questions.text: A 33-year-old male met with a road traffic accident. There is persistent watery discharge mixed with blood from his nose for 3 days which cannot be sniffed back. Which of the following should not be done in this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Plan surgical treatment with functional endoscopic sinus surgery

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

• In the given scenario of a male presenting with watery nasal discharge mixed with blood that cannot be sniffed back following a road traffic accident is suggestive of CSF rhinorrhea. 

• Surgical treatment with functional endoscopic sinus surgery should not be done in this patient.

questions.text: Study the given slide and comment where the given structure drains:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Sphenoethmoidal recess

Ref: Read the text below

Sol

Ethmoid Sinus

• Drainage: anterior cells drain into the ethmoid infundibulum, posterior cells drain into the spheno-

MAXILLARY SINUS
1. Drainage: ethmoid infundibulum (middle meatus, 10–30% have accessory ostium)

FRONTAL SINUS
• frontal recess in anterior middle meatus either medial or lateral to the uncinate (posterior and medial to agar nasi cells), may also be lateral to agar nasi cells

The sphenoidal sinus drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess superior to the superior concha

questions.text: Type of voice in nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Rhinolalia clausa

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:

• Rhinolalia clausa is hyponasality. This is due to nasal obstruction, nasal polyp, sinusitis, adenoid hypertrophy, angiofibroma.

• Rhinolalia aperta is hypernasality. This is due to cleft palate,palatal perforation,palatal palsy

questions.text: In the case of anterior ethmoidal neuralgia, where is the anterior ethmoidal nerve most commonly compressed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

Middle meatus

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

• The middle meatus is the most common site of compression of the anterior ethmoidal nerve causing neuralgia.

• Anterior ethmoidal neuralgia, also known as Sluder’s neuralgia is caused when the anterior ethmoidal nerve, a branch of the nasociliary nerve (which is itself a branch of the ophthalmic nerve, CN V1), is compressed. 

• The most common site of compression is at the middle meatus, where the nerve may be impinged by anatomical variations, inflammation, or other pathologies affecting the paranasal sinuses.

questions.text: The radiological presence of which paranasal sinus appears last in human life
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Frontal sinus

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:

• Maxillary sinus -- Present at birth and radiologically visualized by 4-5 months of age

• Frontal sinus develops in the fourth year of life.  It is radiographically visible in children more than 6 year of age

• Ethmoid sinus is present at birth. Radiologically appreciable by 1 year of age.

• Sphenoid sinus is radiologically appreciable by 4 years of age

• Water’s view is occipitomental view. It shows all sinuses except ethmoid.

• Calwell’s view is occipito frontal view and is best for ethmoid and frontal view.

questions.text: 75-year-old female patient presents with right-sided nasal obstruction with bloody muco-purulent nasal discharge. The following image demonstrates an endoscopic view of the nasal cavity with mass coming from lateral wall. The contralateral nasal cavity is normal. Most appropriate Diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Inverted Papilloma

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

Inverted papilloma (Transitional cell papilloma or Ringertz tumour or Schneiderian papilloma). 

• It is a tumour of the nonolfactory mucosa of nose (Schneiderian membrane) and paranasal sinuses. 

• Most common site of origin is lateral wall of nose in the middle meatus; less commonly it arises from the maxillary, frontal or sphenoid sinus. 

• Clinically, men are affected more than women in the age group of 40–70. It is almost always unilateral and presents with nasal obstruction, nasal discharge and epistaxis. It can invade sinuses or orbit. Orbital involvement causes proptosis, diplopia and lacrimation.

• Computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) show the location and extent of the lesion.

• MRI also helps to differentiate associated secretions in sinus from the actual tumour mass. Biopsy is essential for diagnosis.

• Medial maxillectomy is the treatment of choice.

• It can be performed by lateral rhinotomy or sublabial degloving approach. These days endoscopic approach is pre

Sol

questions.text:
Choose the correct statements regarding the pathology shown in the slide:

1. Disease usually starts in the nose

2. The histological findings are more characteristic and diagnostic in the fibrotic stage.

3. External nose and upper lip giving a “woody” feel

4. Subglottic stenosis may be associated.

5. Nodules are painless and nonulcerative
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

1,3,4 and 5

Reference: Read the text below

Sol:    

• Rhinoscleroma affects most parts of the respiratory tract. It usually starts in the nose, which is affected in most cases, and then spreads to other parts such as the pharynx, which may be involved in about 50% of cases.

• Rhinoscleroma is usually divided clinically and pathologically into three stages, namely:catarrhal (or atrophic) stage, the proliferative (or granulomatous) stage, and the fibrotic (or sclerotic) stage. 

• The histological findings are more characteristic and diagnostic in the proliferative stage. The catarrhal stage has no specific features.

• If clinically suspected, a nasal swab for culture to isolate the microorganisms would confirm the diagnosis. 

STAGES:

1. Atrophic stage. It resembles atrophic rhinitis and is characterized by foul-smelling purulent nasal discharge and crusting.

2. Granulomatous stage. Granulomatous nodules form in nasal mucosa. There is also subdermal infiltration of lower part of external nose and upper lip 
giving a “woody” feel. Nodules are painless and nonulcerative.

3. Cicatricial stage. This causes stenosis of nares, distortion of upper lip, adhesions in the nose, nasopharynx and oropharynx. There may be subglottic stenosis with respiratory distress.

questions.text:
A 43 year old patient has been suffering from Acute Frontal Sinusitis. He has developed non tender swelling on the forehead ( see the picture).

What is the possible diagnosis?

Frontal Mucocele

Ref: Read the text below

• Pott’s puffy tumour is osteomyelitis of frontal bone . This happens as a complication of frontal sinusitis. This is more common in adults .The maxillary osteomyelitis is more common in children.

• Mulberry like nasal polyp is a feature of Rhinosporidiosis

• Mulberry like appearance of nasal mucosa is seen in Inferior turbinate hypertrophy

• Strawberry appearance of nasal mucosa is seen in Sarcoidosis

• Strawberry gingiva means granular appearance of gums and it is seen in wegner’s granulomatosis

questions.text: Given image is a typical finding seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Tympanosclerosis

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

• “Chalk” patches. White areas of tympanosclerosis (arrows) are com-mon findings on examination of the drum. 

• They are of little significance in themselves, and the hearing is often normal. 

• A past history of otorrhea in childhood or grommet insertion is usual. 

• Chalk patches do occur with no apparent past otitis media.

• Extensive tympanosclerosis with a rigid drum is a sequela of past otitis media, and the ossicles, too, may be fixed or non continuous.

choices.text: Medial 24 mm is cartilaginous and lateral 12 mm is bony
Its angled at 45 degrees with horizontal but in children it is more horizontal
The opening of Eustachian tube lies 1.5 cm behind the posterior end of middle turbinate in the nasopharynx
Tensor palati  is the main muscle to open the Eustachian tube

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Eustachian tube?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The opening of Eustachian tube lies 1.5 cm behind the posterior end of middle turbinate in the nasopharynx

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

• Eustachean tube is otherwise known as pharyngotympanic tube, middle ear ventilation tube. It is bony cartilagenous in nature. 

• It connects the middle ear with the nasopharynx. In adults it lies at an angle of 45 degrees to the horizontal plane. 

• In infants this inclination is about 10 degrees. In adults its length is 38mm. For descriptive purposes it can be divided into posterior 1/3 which is 
osseus in nature and anterior 2/3 which is cartilagenous in nature. 

• This tube passes through sinus of Morgagni to enter the nasopharynx and opens 1.5 cm behind the posterior end of inferior turbinate.

• Usually the eustachean tube is closed; it opens during such actions like swallowing, yawning thus equalising the middle ear pressure. Active dilatation of the tube is induced by the tensor palati muscle.

•  Closure of the tube has been attributed to passive reapproximation of tubal walls by extrinsic forces exerted by surrounding elastic fibres.

choices.text: Wave V is the most reliable wave
It’s  is the electrical activity recorded from auditory pathway in response to sound stimulus

questions.text: Brain stem evoked response audiometry  ( BERA) – all are true statements except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ideal screening modality

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

• Brain stem evoked response audiometry, Auditory brain stem response, ABR audiometry, BAER (Brainstem auditory evoked response audiometry).

• Definition: Bera is an objective way of eliciting brain stem potentials in response to audiological click stimuli. These waves are recorded by 
electrodes placed over the scalp. This investigation was first described by Jewett and Williston in 1971. 

• Procedure: The stimulus either in the form of click is transmitted to the ear via a transducer placed in the insert ear phone. The wave forms are 
generated at the level of brain stem are recorded by the placement of electrodes over the scalp.

• The waveforms are numbered by the Roman numerals I - VII. Wave V is the most important and reliable wave. 

• BERA is the gold standard diagnostic test for hearing loss but Otoacoustic emissions (OAE) are the ideal hearing screening modality.

questions.text: The most common site of cholesteatoma in the middle ear cleft is
questions.solution:

Prussak’s space

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

• Prussak's Space is a space in the epitympanum. 

• It is bordered laterally by pars flaccida and medially by the neck of the malleus.

• It is the most common site of cholesteatoma formation.

questions.text: Lateral sinus thrombosis is associated with all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Gradenigo sign

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

LATERAL SINUS THROMBOPHLEBITIS

• Inflammation with subsequent thrombus formation of the sigmoid and/or transverse sinus

• “Picket fence” spiking fevers

• Griesinger’s sign (pain over mastoid from occlusion of the mastoid emissary vein)

• Tobey-Ayer or Queckenstedt’s test(normally external compression of jugular vein results in a rapid increase in CSF pressure of 50–100 mm Hg, compression on the side of lateral sinus thrombosis results in a slow rise or no rise in CSF pressure secondary to obstruction

• Engorgement of retinal veins on fundoscopic examination in a patient of unsafe ear  is known as crowe beck sign.

• Parenteral antibiotics and possible surgical exploration via a mastoidectomy, may require ligation of internal jugular vein recalcitrant disease.

questions.text: Tuberculous otitis media is characterized by all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pain 

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

Tubercular Otitis Media

Important points:

––Seen mainly in children and young adult 

––It is secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis. 

––Route of spread - Mainly through eustachian tube (not blood borne). 

Symptoms:

1. Patients often present with chronic painless otorrhoea (usually foul smelling) which is resistant to antibiotic treatment 

3. Severe conductive type hearing loss. (sometimes due to involvement of labyrinth may be SNHL)

4. Facial nerve palsy may be the presenting symptom in children

5. Cough; fever and night sweats may be present in patients with tuberculous infection in other organ system.

O/E

• Multiple perforations in tympanic membrane (This feature was once considered characteristic of TB but now is seldom seen).

• Middle ear and mastoid are filled with pale granulation tissue(It is a characteristic of tuberculous otitis media)

questions.text:
A 30-year-old male presents with foul smelling ear discharge. On examination external auditory canal was full of granulations and the tympanic membrane appeared as the picture given below. Which of the following will be part of management:

1.     Antibiotics

2.      Decongestants

3.      Radical mastoidectomy

4.      Modified radical mastoidectomy

5.      Myringoplasty

Correct Answer (D)

1,2 and 4

• Since reconstruction of hearing is not done in radical mastoidectomy, so MRM is preferred over radical mastoidectomy in the treatment of unsafe CSOM to give the patient a hearing ear besides making the ear safe and dry.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female, with history of left modified radical mastoidectomy 2 months prior for cholesteatoma, presented with one-week history of foul smelling blood stained ear discharge,fever, otalgia, neck pain, and neck swelling, with reduced neck movement. On examination, she appeared ill with high spiking fever and the left postauricular wound dehiscence was discharging pus.All of the following statements are true regarding diagnosis except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Gradenigo triad raises the possibility of involvement of 5 and 10 nerve.

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

LATERAL SINUS THROMBOPHLEBITIS

• Inflammation with subsequent thrombus formation of the sigmoid and/or transverse sinus

• “Picket fence” spiking fevers

• Griesinger’s sign (pain over mastoid from occlusion of the mastoid emmisary vein)

• Tobey-Ayer or Queckenstedt’s test(normally external compression of jugular vein results in a rapid increase in CSF pressure of 50–100 mm Hg, compression on the side of lateral sinus thrombosis results in a slow rise or no rise in CSF pressure secondary to obstruction

• Parenteral antibiotics and possible surgical exploration via a mastoidectomy, may require ligation of internal jugular vein recalcitrant disease.

 Meningitis is the most common and Brain abscess second most common intra cranial complication.

 Ironing of mastoid is the earliest sign, tenderness is the most common.

 Gradenigo triad raises the possibility of involvement of 5 and 6 nerve.

questions.text: A 74-year-old patient with complaints of vertigo, dizziness and progressive, bilateral sensorineural hearing loss.She complains of increasing hearing loss for over 15 years. She also undergoes computed tomography (CT) scanning of the temporal bones. The scans are shown as follows.Which of the following will be key finding on PTA :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cookie Bite Audiogram.

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

• The diagnosis is otosclerosis with cochlear involvement or fenestral and cochlear otosclerosis. The ‘double ring’ sign around the cochlea on CT is typical of this disease. 

• Osteogenesis imperfecta can lead to a similar CT appearance but is far less common in the temporal bone.

• Audiogram will show typical Cookie Bite Audiogram

questions.text: All of the following are hallmark features of pathology shown in the given image except :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Copious otorrhea. 

Ref: Read the text below.

Sol:-

• There may be a huge conductive loss but occasionally the disease may bridge an ossicular gap-'silent cholesteatoma'.  

• Usually scanty. The offensive odour is due to the osteitis with secondary infection. 

• Hearing loss and otorrhoea are the usual symptoms. Earache suggests a complication. 

• The perforation is usually marginal but disease can occur behind an intact eardrum. 

• Vertigo indicates perilabyrinthitis and potential spread to the inner ear; usually by fistularization of the lateral semicircular canal and rarely the promontory.

questions.text: On the day of delivery, a newborn baby is undergoing a screening test for hearing. Which of the following tests is likely to be performed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Otoacoustic emissions (OAE)

Ref: Read the text below    

Sol:

• A newborn baby on the same day of delivery will undergo the Otoacoustic emissions (OAE) test as a screening test for hearing.

• Universal Newborn Hearing Screening (UNHS) has become a standard practice in most developed countries. 

• The identification of all newborns with hearing loss before 6 months has become an attainable and realistic goal. 

• The goal is to screen newborn babies before 1 month of age, diagnose hearing loss before 3 months of age and start intervention as early as possible,or latest by 6 months of age.

questions.text: Audiogram shown in the image is seen in?

questions.text: A female patient with hearing loss is examined and is found to be Rinne negative at 256 Hz and 512 Hz, while Rinne positive at 1024 Hz What is the expected air conduction and bone conduction gap?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  

30-45 dB

Ref:Read the text below

Sol :  

• A prediction of the air bone gap can be made using tuning forks of 256, 512 and 1024 Hz:

• A Rinne test negative for 256 Hz but positive for 512 Hz indicates airbone gap of 20-30 dB.

• A Rinne test negative for 256 Hz and 512 Hz but positive for 1024 Hz indicates airbone gap of 30-45dB.

• A Rinne test negative for 256 Hz, 512 Hz, and 1024 Hz indicates airbone gap of 45-60 dB.

questions.text:
Arrange the auditory pathway in order from periphery to centre

a. Eight nerve

b. Inferior colliculus

c. Medial geniculate body

d. Ventral / dorsal cochlear nucleus

e. Superior Olivary nucleus

f. Lateral lemniscus

g. Auditory cortex
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) a d e f b c g
Ref: Read the text below.
Sol:-
Auditory pathway--ECOLI MA
E - Eight nerve
C- Ventral / dorsal cochlear nucleus
O - Superior Olivary nucleus
L - Lateral lemniscus
I - Inferior colliculus
M - Medial geniculate body
A - Auditory cortex

questions.text: A patient with ear wax underwent syringing. During syringing, patient developed syncopal episode. Stimulation of which nerve is responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 
Arnold's nerve
Sol :  

• The nerve responsible for a vasovagal attack during syringing of the ear is Arnold nerve branch of vagus nerve. 
• Stimulation of the vagus nerve, such as during syringing of the ear, can cause a decrease in heart rate and blood pressure, leading to a vasovagal attack.

questions.text: A patient presents to ENT OPD with pulsatile tinnitus,reddish mass behind tympanic membrane. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) Glomus tumour
Sol :  

                          Glomus Tumors (Paragangliomas, Chemodectomas)
Glomus Tumor: slow growing, benign tumor although locally destructive (expansive, bone eroding) of the chemoreceptive cells (paraganglion cells, neural crest in origin) distributed along parasympathetic nerves in the base of skull, neck, and chest
• Most common benign tumor of the temporal bone of adults (rare in pediatrics)
Glomus Vagale: arise from paraganglia around the vagus nerve at the base of skull
• SSx: pulsatile tinnitus (most common symptom), hearing loss, cranial nerve palsies, aural discharge, otalgia, dizziness (invasion of the labyrinth), reddish middle ear mass, BROWN’S SIGN (BLANCHING OF THE TM WITH POSITIVE PRESSURE)
• Rx: surgical resection after preoperative embolization or primary
radiation therapy for nonoperable candidates, advanced tumors, or presence of residual disease

questions.text: The first staging system of TMRs was proposed by Sade and Berco, classifying pars tensa retraction by otoscopic image into stage I till IV, based on the reversibility of the retraction after ventilation. Choose the most appropriate match regarding the classification :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 4a2c3d1b
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
Sade classification of retraction of pars tensa
Grade 1 – mild retraction 
Grade 2—severe retraction—retracted TM touching incus or stapes
Grade 3—Atelectatic TM—TM touching promontory but moves on seigelisation
Grade 4---Adhesive TM--TM touching promontory, does not move on seigelisationos classification of pars flaccida
Tos classification of pars flaccida
Stage I: Pars flaccida is dimpled and is more retracted than normal. It is not adherent to the malleus.
Stage II: In this stage the retraction pocket is adherent to the handle of malleus. The full extent of the retraction pocket can be clearly seen.
Stage III: In this stage part of the retraction pocket may be hidden. There may also be associated erosion of the outer attic wall (scutum).
Stage IV: In this stage there is definite severe erosion of the outer attic wall. The extent of the retraction pocket cannot be clearly seen as most of it are hidden from the view.

questions.text: A patient presents in emergency with high grade fever, seizure and altered sensorium. On examination hemianopia was documented. On history he was known case of CSOM and was under treatment. and was undergoing CSOM treatment. Immediate CT was done. Choose the most appropriate Diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) Temporal lobe abscess
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:

Otogenic Brain Abscess:
 Temporal lobe abscess: Cerebellar abscess = 2:1.
 Organisms: Commonest: Anaerobic streptococci.
 Nominal Aphasia, homonymous hemianopia, focal epilepsy.

Mastoidectomy:
Canal wall down (CWD) procedures:
• Modified radical mastoidectomy
• Radical mastoidectomy
• Atticotomy
Canal wall up (CWU) procedures:
• Cortical mastoidectomy (Schwartz operation)
Combined approach tympanoplasty

choices.text: Botulinum toxin injection is the treatment of choice
EMG guidance is must during botulinum toxin injection

questions.text: All are true about abductor spasmodic dysphonia except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) Patient has strangulated voice
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
• In adductor spasmodic dysphonia, patient has choked voive ( strangulated voice)
• In abductor SD, the voice is breathy.

choices.text: Racemose Epinephrine nebulization is helpful in the management
Repeated Direct laryngoscopy can aggravate laryngeal oedema

questions.text: All of the following are true about acute epiglottitis except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) Racemose Epinephrine nebulization is helpful in the management
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
The racemose epinephrine nebulisation is helpful in management of acute laryngotracheobronchitis ( croup)
Tripod sign means patient prefers to sit down bending forwards. This helps child breathe.
Acute laryngotracheobranchitis (croup)
1. Affects the larynx, trachea and bronchi
2. Organism: Viral ( Parainfluenza) 
3. Age group; 3 mth -3 yrs
4. Male> female 
. Clinical Features:
a. Onset -gradual
b. Fever(39-40 degC)  .
c. Dry, harsh cough (Croupy cough)
d. Hoarseness and inspiratory stridor           
e.  Mucosal swelling especially of the sub-glottic area which causes Airway obstruction
Treatment:                                                      
o Hospitalisation
o I/v fluids
o I/v steroids : to reduce edema especially when child in distress
o Humidified air to soften crusts
o Nebulization
o Racemic Adrenaline via a respirator
o Intubation / tracheostomy may be needed
Antibiotics are only given to prevent secondary infection

choices.text: Vertical partial laryngectomy is done for T2 N0 glottic malignancy
Horizontal partial laryngectomy should be done only if both vocal cords are normal
Good pulmonary reserve is needed for partial laryngectomy
Patient has permanent tracheostomy after partial laryngectomy

questions.text: All are true about partial laryngectomy except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) Patient has permanent tracheostomy after partial laryngectomy
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
• Horizontal partial laryngectomy is done for T2N0M0 supraglottic cancer. 
• The pre-requisite is the growth should be limited to supraglottis and both vocal cords are free and mobile. 
• The lung functions should be also good
• Vertical partial laryngectomy is done for T2N0Mo glottic cancer. The growth should be limited to one side and other side should be free.

choices.text: Identifying the mobility of vocal cord
Identification of preservation of normal mucosal wave of vocal cord
Malignant lesions are seen in blue color

questions.text: Laryngeal videostroboscopy helps to differentiate benign from early malignant lesions of vocal cord by
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)   Identification of preservation of normal mucosal wave of vocal cord
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
Stroboscopy: This is an excellent tool for examining the movements of the vocal cords  in their various phases.
Stroboscopic images are generated  using a flashing light source create the illusion of slow motion .  
Strobolaryngoscopy takes advantage of these principles by producing intermittent light flashes in close relation to the frequency of the vocal-fold vibration. 
A microphone picks up the frequency of the examinee's sustained voice, which triggers the stroboscopic light source. 
With the provision that the vocal vibrations are periodic, a frequency of light flashes equal to the vocal frequency produces a clear, still image of the same portion to the vibratory cycle.
The following parameters can be assessed using stroboscope:
a. The fundamental speech frequency of the patient
b. Periodicity: It refers to the regularity of the successive vocal fold movements
c. Symmetry: Normal vocal folds vibrate in a symmetric manner
d. Glottic closure: During normal vibratory phase the membranous portion of the vocal cord firmly apposes, while the posterior glottic chink may be open.
e. Mucosal wave: The pattern of light traveling from mediolaterally along the superior surface of the vocal fold during vibration under illumination is referred to as the mucosal wave. It is a correlate of the pliable cover (epithelium and superficial lamina propria) of the vocal fold being displaced relative to the body of the vocal fold (vocalis muscle). Focal abnormalities of mucosal wave help to localize pathology in the vocal fold.. This helps to differentiate benign from malignant lesion.

questions.text: All of the following involve the posterior part of larynx except

Sol:

Stroboscopy

• A microphone picks up the frequency of the examinee's sustained voice, which triggers the stroboscopic light source. 
• With the provision that the vocal vibrations are periodic, a frequency of light flashes equal to the vocal frequency produces a clear, still image of the same portion to the vibratory cycle.

questions.text: A case of carcinoma larynx with the involvement of Left vocal cord, left aryepiglottic fold, left ventricular band and invading into paraglottic space. Which of the following statements is true for the managements of this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) Total Laryngectomy and radiotherapy
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
• This is the stage T3 of cancer larynx as there is involvement of paraglottic space. 
• Therefore total laryngectomy and radiotherapy is required in this case.

Functional aphonia (hysterical aphonia)
Emotionally labile females (15-30 yrs)
Vocal cords : Abducted position when trying to phonate
Adduct only on coughing
Treatment : Psychotherapy

choices.text: Superior constrictor and styloglossus make the bed of tonsil
Internal carotid artery lie one inch lateral to tonsillar bed
Commonest source of bleeding during tonsillectomy is paratonsillar vein ( descending palatine vein)
In tonsillectomy, primary haemorrhage is within first 24 hours and should be re-explored immediately

questions.text: All of the following are true statements regarding tonsil except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) In tonsillectomy, primary haemorrhage is within first 24 hours and should be re-explored immediately
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
(i) Reactionary hemorrhage is seen within 24 hours of tonsillectomy. It is due to slippage of ligature and it should be immediately re-explored under GA.
(ii) Secondary hemorrhage seen after 24 hours of tonsillectomy and commonly seen after 5th day of tonsillectomy. It is due to infection of tonsillar fossa and is managed with I/V antibiotics.

choices.text: Extracapsular approach is best for cold surgery
Sleep apnea with large tonsil is an indication
Adenoids should also be removed if significantly enlarged
Griesel’s syndrome is the most common complication in very young children.

questions.text: True regarding tonsillectomy in children are all except –
questions.solution:
Correct Answer(D) Griesel’s syndrome is the most common complication in very young children.
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
• Grisel’s syndrome, defined as subluxation of the atlanto-axial joint, not associated with trauma or bone disease, is found primarily in children. This syndrome has been observed after otolaryngologic procedures such as adenotonsilectomy. It is an uncommon complication.
• It presents with torticollis, neck stiffness. X-rays and computed tomography scans of the cervical spine can confirm the diagnosis. Early management, consisting of cervical immobilization and medical treatment, is considered the key factor for a satisfactory outcome. Neurological complications have been reported in the literature, ranging from mild paresthesia, clonus, to quadriplegia or acute respiratory failure and death so neurosurgical consultation is required.This  is a rare complication.

choices.text: Epstein-Barr virus is an etiological agent
Bilateral conductive deafness in an adult patient is a common presentation
Cervical lymph node metastasis is seen in 75% patients
Commonest histopathological type is undifferentiated carcinoma

questions.text: All of the following are true about nasopharyngeal carcinoma except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) Bilateral conductive deafness in an adult patient is a common presentation
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
• The nasopharyngeal carcinoma presents with unilateral conductive hearing loss in an adult patient. 
• Neck node is the commonest presentation . it is more common in China. 
• Radiotherapy is the treatment of choice for all stages of nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

choices.text: Weber Fergusson’s trans maxillary  approach is ideal for angiofibroma limited to nose & nasopharynx
Superior margin of sphenopalatine foramen is the most common site of origin

questions.text: All of the following are true about juvenile angiofibroma except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) Weber Fergusson’s transmaxillary  approach is ideal for angiofibroma limited to nose & nasopharynx
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
•  Angiofibroma is the most common benign tumour of nasopharynx seen in adolescent males. It originates from sphenopalatine foramen. It’s a highly vascular tumour. 
• CECT scan shows Hollman Miller ( =Antral) sign. Surgery is treatment of choice. Pre-op embolisation will reduce blood loss. 
• Pre-op Estrogen, Flutamide ( androgen antagonist) are helpful in reducing blood loss. Debulking or biopsy of this tumour is never done as it is a highly vascular tumour.
• Tumours confined to nasopharynx can be approached through Wilson’s transpalatal approach.
• But tumours extending to cheek would need trans- maxillary approach using weber fergusson incision

questions.text: A singer is finding difficulty in raising the pitch. On examination vocal cords were depressed and bowing. Which of the muscle may be involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) Cricothyroid muscle.
Ref:Read the text below
Sol
• Cricothyroid muscle is a primary muscle that changes pitch:
• The cricothyroid muscle pulls the thyroid cartilage forward and down, which stretches and tightens the vocal folds.
• This increases the distance between the thyroid notch and the arytenoids, which makes the vocal folds vibrate faster and produce a higher pitch

questions.text: Which of the following stain can be used for a laryngeal mass seen during laryngoscopy examination
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) Supravital statin.
Ref:Read the text below
Sol
• Supravital staining with toluidine blue is a technique that can help diagnose laryngeal carcinoma.
• It's used in combination with microscopic laryngoscopy.

choices.text: Anterior Jugular veins and inferior thyroid veins are the most common site of bleeding
In pediatric tracheostomy, a circular ring of anterior tracheal wall is never removed
High tracheostomy is indicated in carcinoma larynx.
Dead space is increased  in tracheostomy.

questions.text: All of the following are true statements regarding the tube shown below except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) Dead space is increased  in tracheostomy.
Ref: Read the text below    
Sol:
• High trachestomy means when it starts from first ring. It is only done in a case of cancer larynx. Otherwise, the level of tracheostomy is 2nd and 3rd rings. 
• If we involve first ring, it can cause subglottic stenosis later on. 
• In pediatric trachestomy, we don’t remove circular ring of anterior tracheal wall because this can lead to tracheomalacia later on. 
• In adults we do remove a circular ring of anterior tracheal wall to place the tube.

choices.text: Physiological enlargement continues upto 6 years of age
Adenoidectomy is contraindicated in submucous cleft palate
Digital palpation of adenoid tissue should be avoided before removal in adenoidectomy

questions.text: Which of the following is not a true statement regarding adenoids
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) Digital palpation of adenoid tissue should be avoided before removal in adenoidectomy
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
Adenoids: (Nasopharyngeal Tonsil)
Definition; Adenoids are lymphoid tissue located at the junction of nasopharyngeal roof and the posterior pharyngeal wall
Features:
1. Are lined by ciliated columnar epithelium
2. Have no capsule/crypts
3. Are present at birth not visible on X-ray in children under I month of age
4. Clinically seen by the 4th month
5. Visible radiographically in children more than 6 month of age
6. physiologically grow upto 6 years of age
7. Involution after puberty
Before adenoidectomy, the adenoid mass should be palpated before surgery to confirm the diagnosis and to rule out any abnormal vessel overlying the adenoid mass

choices.text: Serous otitis media in children with adenoid hypertrophy
Tubotympanic otitis media in children with adenoid hypertrophy
Adenoid Hypertrophy in children with atticoantral CSOM
Children with history of mouth breathing

questions.text: Adenoidectomy & Myringotomy with grommet insertion is treatment of choice for?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) Serous otitis media in children with adenoid hypertrophy
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
• Adenoidectomy with myringotomy/grommet insertion is the treatment of choice for patients with adenoid hypertrophy and serous otitis media

choices.text: Examination of pharynx shows a midline bulge on posterior pharyngeal wall
Mostly presents as a paediatric airway emergency
X ray soft tissue neck lateral view shows widening of prevertebral shadow
Retropharyngeal space extends from skull base to bifurcation of trachea

questions.text: A 12-year-old previously healthy child  presented to the emergency department with fever, throat pain, and difficulty breathing. The previous history was unremarkable, except for perforated appendicitis 15 months prior. One week prior to admission, the patient reported the symptom of a sore throat that improved slightly after 2 days of self-prescribed penicillin. However, a worsening sore throat returned the day prior to admission. In the ED, the patient was found to have a right-sided sore throat, pain while swallowing, odynophagia, poor oral (p.o.) intake, right neck tenderness, and a fever of 40.1°C. The patient also reported a recent development of trismus and muffled “hot potato” voice. X-Ray demonstrate unilateral soft tissue swelling posterior to the pharynx, with a widening of the prevertebral soft tissue. All of the following are true about diagnosis except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) Examination of pharynx shows a midline bulge on posterior pharyngeal wall
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
Retropharyngeal Space - Between the buccopharyngeal fascia covering the pharyngeal constrictor  & the prevertebral fascia
 * Extends from base of skull to bifurcation of trachea
 * Divided by a fibrous raphe into 2 (spaces of Gilette)
 * Abscess causes U/L bulge on post pharyngeal wall
Acute retropharyngeal abscess - Commonly seen in children < 3yrs
 * Results of suppuration of retropharyngeal LN
 * In adults - from penetrating injury of post. pharyngeal wall
C/F : * Dysphagia & difficulty in breathing (prominent symp)
 * Stridor & croupy cough
 * Torticollis
 * Bulge in post. Pharyngeal wall (usually seen on one side of midline)
 Xray STN lat. view - widening of prevertebral shadow
T/t - I & D without GA, antibiotics

questions.text: A male in 2nd decade of life has multiple recurrent nasal bleeding with recurrent nasal blockage. On endoscopy following image seen , and Contrast enhanced CT revealed a large, ill-defined enhancing soft tissue mass filling the chonae, nasopharynx and bilateral nasal cavity. Which of the following is contraindicated in the patient :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) Debulking of the tumor 
Ref: Read the text below
Sol: 
• Angiofibroma is the most common benign tumour of nasopharynx seen in adolescent males. It originates from sphenopalatine foramen. 
• It’s a highly vascular tumour. CECT scan shows Hollman Miller ( =Antral) sign. Surgery is treatment of choice. 
• Pre-op embolisation will reduce blood loss. 
• Pre-op Estrogen, Flutamide ( androgen antagonist) are helpful in reducing blood loss.
• Debulking or biopsy of this tumour is never done as it is a highly vascular tumour.
• Tumours confined to nasopharynx can be approached through Wilson’s transpalatal approach. But tumours extending to cheek would need trans- maxillary approach using weber fergusson incision.
